messageBody:
Paul Tremblay scripsit:

> What happens if there are a lot of minimal pairs in a language, but they
> happened to be all homophones--are they still considered minimal pairs?

No, of course not.

> Maybe this would never the case with English, but I understand that
> Chinese consists of a huge number of homophones, which the writing
> system distinguishes.

(This is a digression, but in fact the massive mergers that produced
modern Mandarin Chinese from Middle Chinese during the 14th century were
compensated for by the transformation of almost all Chinese words from
monosyllabic to multisyllabic, either by adding meaningless suffixes
or by forming compounds. This was greatly disguised by continuing to
write Middle Chinese until the early part of the 20th century, exploiting
the high redundancy in the writing system to carry the meaning. If any
such passage in written Chinese were read out literally as written in
either Mandarin or any other descendant of Middle Chinese, it would be
completely unintelligible. Modern written Chinese is now tied closely to
Mandarin, and cannot be plausibly read in any other variety of Chinese.)

> But, now as I write this, I see your point. Even if 50 million English
> speakers do pronounce whale and wail differently, there simply aren't
> enough words to justify making each one a phoneme, and since QS is based
> on phonemes, we shouldn't have separate letters (or so the original post
> wonders).

Exactly. This condition is called having a low functional load, as
BPJ said.

> Yea, now I get it! Someone wrote me off line explaining. Any Noam
> Chimksey jokes?

Well, okay.

Q: How do you get Noam Chomsky to shut up?

A: Ask him a question about linguistics.
